location: England, London, Old Bailey, Warwick Passage
description:
A large octagonal building surrounded by what appears to be an ambulatory was constructed sometime after 120 CE on the site of the modern Old Bailey building. Prior to this the site appears to have been the center of the glass working industry in Roman London.

The structure has been interpreted as a Romano-Celtic temple, though not much more is known and Perring and Brigham now prefer to interpret it as a 'secular' structure.
bibliography: Hall, J, and J Shepherd. “Places of Worship in Roman London and Beyond.” In Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain, 2008.
Haynes, I. “Art in Roman London.” In London Under Ground: The Archaeology of a City, 66, 2000.
Heathcote, J. “Excavation Round-up 1988, Part 1: City of London.” London Archaeologist 6, no. 2 (2008).
Merrifieild, R. “The London Hunter- God and His Signifi Cance in the History of Londinium.” In Interpreting Roman London: Papers in Memory of Hugh Chapman. Oxbow, 1996.
Perring, D. Roman London (The Archaeology of London), 1991.
Schofield, John. Archaeology in the City of London, 1907-1991: A Guide to Records of Excavations. Vol. 1. Museum of London, 1998.

Shepherd, J, and A Wardle. “The Basinghall Glass in Context.” In Glass Working on the Margins of Roman London: Excavations at 35 Basinghall Street, City of London, 2005, London, Vol. Monograph 70. MOLAS, 2015.
